013package org.apache.juneau.annotation;
014
015import static java.lang.annotation.ElementType.*;
016import static java.lang.annotation.RetentionPolicy.*;
017
018import java.beans.*;
019import java.lang.annotation.*;
020import java.util.*;
021
022import org.apache.juneau.*;
023import org.apache.juneau.swap.*;
024
025/**
026 * Used to tailor how beans get interpreted by the framework.
027 *
028 * <p>
029 * Can be used in the following locations:
030 * <ul>
031 *    <li>Bean classes and parent interfaces.
032 *    <li><ja>@Rest</ja>-annotated classes and <ja>@RestOp</ja>-annotated methods when an {@link #on()} value is specified.
033 * </ul>
034 *
035 * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
036 *    <li class='link'><a class="doclink" href="https://juneau.apache.org/docs/topics/BeanAnnotation">@Bean Annotation</a>
037 * </ul>
038 */
039@Documented
040@Target({METHOD,TYPE})
041@Retention(RUNTIME)
042@Inherited
043@Repeatable(BeanAnnotation.Array.class)
044@ContextApply(BeanAnnotation.Applier.class)
045public @interface Bean {
046
047    /**
048     * Optional description for the exposed API.
049     *
050     * @return The annotation value.
051     * @since 9.2.0
052     */
053    String[] description() default {};
054
055    /**
056    * Bean dictionary.
057    *
058    * <p>
059    * The list of classes that make up the bean dictionary for all properties in this class and all subclasses.
060    *
061    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
062    *    <li class='ja'>{@link Beanp#dictionary()}
063    *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#dictionary()}
064    *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#dictionary_replace()}
065    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanDictionary(Class...)}
066    * </ul>
067    *
068    * @return The annotation value.
069    */
070   Class<?>[] dictionary() default {};
071
072   /**
073    * POJO example.
074    *
075    * <p>
076    * Specifies an example of the specified class in Simplified JSON format.
077    *
078    * <p>
079    * Examples are used in cases such as POJO examples in Swagger documents.
080    *
081    * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
082    * <p class='bjava'>
083    *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(example=<js>"{foo:'bar'}"</js>)
084    *    <jk>public class</jk> MyClass {...}
085    * </p>
086    *
087    * <h5 class='section'>Notes:</h5><ul>
088    *    <li class='note'>
089    *       Setting applies to specified class and all subclasses.
090    *    <li class='note'>
091    *       Keys are the class of the example.
092    *       <br>Values are JSON 5 representation of that class.
093    *    <li class='note'>
094    *       POJO examples can also be defined on classes via the following:
095    *       <ul class='spaced-list'>
096    *          <li>A static field annotated with {@link Example @Example}.
097    *          <li>A static method annotated with {@link Example @Example} with zero arguments or one {@link BeanSession} argument.
098    *          <li>A static method with name <c>example</c> with no arguments or one {@link BeanSession} argument.
099    *       </ul>
100    *    <li class='note'>
101    *       Supports <a class="doclink" href="https://juneau.apache.org/docs/topics/DefaultVarResolver">VarResolver.DEFAULT</a> (e.g. <js>"$C{myConfigVar}"</js>).
102    * </ul>
103    *
104    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
105    *    <li class='ja'>{@link Example}
106    * </ul>
107    *
108    * @return The annotation value.
109    */
110   String example() default "";
111
112   /**
113    * Bean property excludes.
114    *
115    * <p>
116    * Specifies a list of properties that should be excluded from {@link BeanMap#entrySet()}.
117    *
118    * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
119    * <p class='bjava'>
120    *    <jc>// Exclude the 'city' and 'state' properties from the Address class.</jc>
121    *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(excludeProperties=<js>"city,state"</js>})
122    *    <jk>public class</jk> Address {...}
123    * </p>
124    *
125    * <h5 class='section'>Notes:</h5><ul>
126    *    <li class='note'>
127    *       {@link #xp()} is a shortened synonym for this value.
128    * </ul>
129    *
130    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
131    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanPropertiesExcludes(Class, String)}
132    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanPropertiesExcludes(String, String)}
133    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanPropertiesExcludes(Map)}
134    * </ul>
135    *
136    * @return The annotation value.
137    */
138   String excludeProperties() default "";
139
140   /**
141    * Find fluent setters.
142    *
143    * <p>
144    * When <jk>true</jk>, fluent setters will be detected on beans.
145    *
146    * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
147    * <p class='bjava'>
148    *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(findFluentSetters=<jk>true</jk>)
149    *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
150    *       <jk>public int</jk> getId() {...}
151    *       <jk>public</jk> MyBean id(<jk>int</jk> <jv>id</jv>) {...}
152    *    }
153    * </p>
154    *
155    * <p>
156    * Fluent setters must have the following attributes:
157    * <ul>
158    *    <li>Public.
159    *    <li>Not static.
160    *    <li>Take in one parameter.
161    *    <li>Return the bean itself.
162    * </ul>
163    *
164    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
165    *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#findFluentSetters()}
166    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#findFluentSetters()}
167    * </ul>
168    *
169    * @return The annotation value.
170    */
171   boolean findFluentSetters() default false;
172
173   /**
174    * Implementation class.
175    *
176    * <p>
177    * For interfaces and abstract classes this method can be used to specify an implementation class for the
178    * interface/abstract class so that instances of the implementation class are used when instantiated (e.g. during a
179    * parse).
180    *
181    * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
182    * <p class='bjava'>
183    *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(implClass=MyInterfaceImpl.<jk>class</jk>)
184    *    <jk>public class</jk> MyInterface {...}
185    * <p>
186    *
187    * @return The annotation value.
188    */
189   Class<?> implClass() default void.class;
190
191   /**
192    * Bean property interceptor.
193    *
194    * <p>
195    * Bean interceptors can be used to intercept calls to getters and setters and alter their values in transit.
196    *
197    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
198    *    <li class='jc'>{@link BeanInterceptor}
199    * </ul>
200    *
201    * @return The annotation value.
202    */
203   Class<? extends BeanInterceptor<?>> interceptor() default BeanInterceptor.Void.class;
204
205   /**
206    * Identifies a class to be used as the interface class for this and all subclasses.
207    *
208    * <p>
209    * When specified, only the list of properties defined on the interface class will be used during serialization.
210    * Additional properties on subclasses will be ignored.
211    *
212    * <p class='bjava'>
213    *    <jc>// Parent class</jc>
214    *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(interfaceClass=A.<jk>class</jk>)
215    *    <jk>public abstract class</jk> A {
216    *       <jk>public</jk> String <jf>f0</jf> = <js>"f0"</js>;
217    *    }
218    *
219    *    <jc>// Sub class</jc>
220    *    <jk>public class</jk> A1 <jk>extends</jk> A {
221    *       <jk>public</jk> String <jf>f1</jf> = <js>"f1"</js>;
222    *    }
223    *
224    *    <jc>// Produces "{f0:'f0'}"</jc>
225    *    String <jv>json</jv> = Json5Serializer.<jsf>DEFAULT</jsf>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> A1());
226    * </p>
227    *
228    * <p>
229    * Note that this annotation can be used on the parent class so that it filters to all child classes,
230    * or can be set individually on the child classes.
231    *
232    * @return The annotation value.
233    */
234   Class<?> interfaceClass() default void.class;
235
236   /**
237    * Dynamically apply this annotation to the specified classes.
238    *
239    * <p>
240    * Used in conjunction with {@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#applyAnnotations(Class...)} to dynamically apply an annotation to an existing class.
241    * It is ignored when the annotation is applied directly to classes.
242    *
243    * <h5 class='section'>Valid patterns:</h5>
244    * <ul class='spaced-list'>
245    *  <li>Classes:
246    *       <ul>
247    *          <li>Fully qualified:
248    *             <ul>
249    *                <li><js>"com.foo.MyClass"</js>
250    *             </ul>
251    *          <li>Fully qualified inner class:
252    *             <ul>
253    *                <li><js>"com.foo.MyClass$Inner1$Inner2"</js>
254    *             </ul>
255    *          <li>Simple:
256    *             <ul>
257    *                <li><js>"MyClass"</js>
258    *             </ul>
259    *          <li>Simple inner:
260    *             <ul>
261    *                <li><js>"MyClass$Inner1$Inner2"</js>
262    *                <li><js>"Inner1$Inner2"</js>
263    *                <li><js>"Inner2"</js>
264    *             </ul>
265    *       </ul>
266    *    <li>A comma-delimited list of anything on this list.
267    * </ul>
268    *
269    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
270    *    <li class='link'><a class="doclink" href="https://juneau.apache.org/docs/topics/DynamicallyAppliedAnnotations">Dynamically Applied Annotations</a>
271    * </ul>
272    *
273    * @return The annotation value.
274    */
275   String[] on() default {};
276
277   /**
278    * Dynamically apply this annotation to the specified classes.
279    *
280    * <p>
281    * Identical to {@link #on()} except allows you to specify class objects instead of a strings.
282    *
283    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
284    *    <li class='link'><a class="doclink" href="https://juneau.apache.org/docs/topics/DynamicallyAppliedAnnotations">Dynamically Applied Annotations</a>
285    * </ul>
286    *
287    * @return The annotation value.
288    */
289   Class<?>[] onClass() default {};
290
291   /**
292    * Synonym for {@link #properties()}.
293    *
294    * @return The annotation value.
295    */
296   String p() default "";
297
298   /**
299    * Bean property includes.
300    *
301    * <p>
302    * The set and order of names of properties associated with a bean class.
303    *
304    * <p>
305    * The order specified is the same order that the entries will be returned by the {@link BeanMap#entrySet()} and
306    * related methods.
307    *
308    * <p>
309    * This value is entirely optional if you simply want to expose all the getters and public fields on
310    * a class as bean properties.
311    * <br>However, it's useful if you want certain getters to be ignored or you want the properties to be
312    * serialized in a particular order.
313    * <br>Note that on IBM JREs, the property order is the same as the order in the source code,
314    * whereas on Oracle JREs, the order is entirely random.
315    *
316    * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
317    * <p class='bjava'>
318    *    <jc>// Address class with only street/city/state properties (in that order).</jc>
319    *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(properties=<js>"street,city,state"</js>)
320    *    <jk>public class</jk> Address {...}
321    * </p>
322    *
323    * <h5 class='section'>Notes:</h5><ul>
324    *    <li class='note'>
325    *       {@link #p()} is a shortened synonym for this value.
326    * </ul>
327    *
328    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
329    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanProperties(Class, String)}
330    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanProperties(String, String)}
331    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanProperties(Map)}
332    * </ul>
333    *
334    * @return The annotation value.
335    */
336   String properties() default "";
337
338   /**
339    * Associates a {@link PropertyNamer} with this bean to tailor the names of the bean properties.
340    *
341    * <p>
342    * Property namers are used to transform bean property names from standard form to some other form.
343    *
344    * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
345    * <p class='bjava'>
346    *    <jc>// Define a class with dashed-lowercase property names.</jc>
347    *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(propertyNamer=PropertyNamerDashedLC.<jk>class</jk>)
348    *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {...}
349    * </p>
350    *
351    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
352    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#propertyNamer(Class)}
353    * </ul>
354    *
355    * @return The annotation value.
356    */
357   Class<? extends PropertyNamer> propertyNamer() default PropertyNamer.Void.class;
358
359   /**
360    * Read-only bean properties.
361    *
362    * <p>
363    * Specifies one or more properties on a bean that are read-only despite having valid getters.
364    * Serializers will serialize such properties as usual, but parsers will silently ignore them.
365    *
366    * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
367    * <p class='bjava'>
368    *    <jc>// Exclude the 'city' and 'state' properties from being parsed, but not serialized.</jc>
369    *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(readOnlyProperties=<js>"city,state"</js>})
370    *    <jk>public class</jk> Address {...}
371    * </p>
372    *
373    * <h5 class='section'>Notes:</h5><ul>
374    *    <li class='note'>
375    *       {@link #ro()} is a shortened synonym for this value.
376    * </ul>
377    *
378    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
379    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanPropertiesReadOnly(Class, String)}
380    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanPropertiesReadOnly(String, String)}
381    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanPropertiesReadOnly(Map)}
382    * </ul>
383    *
384    * @return The annotation value.
385    */
386   String readOnlyProperties() default "";
387
388   /**
389    * Synonym for {@link #readOnlyProperties()}.
390    *
391    * @return The annotation value.
392    */
393   String ro() default "";
394
395   /**
396    * Sort bean properties in alphabetical order.
397    *
398    * <p>
399    * When <jk>true</jk>, all bean properties will be serialized and access in alphabetical order.
400    * <br>Otherwise, the natural order of the bean properties is used which is dependent on the JVM vendor.
401    *
402    * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
403    * <p class='bjava'>
404    *    <jc>// Sort bean properties alphabetically during serialization.</jc>
405    *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(sort=<jk>true</jk>)
406    *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {...}
407    * </p>
408    *
409    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
410    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#sortProperties()}
411    * </ul>
412    *
413    * @return The annotation value.
414    */
415   boolean sort() default false;
416
417   /**
418    * Identifies a stop class for the annotated class.
419    *
420    * <p>
421    * Identical in purpose to the stop class specified by {@link Introspector#getBeanInfo(Class, Class)}.
422    * Any properties in the stop class or in its base classes will be ignored during analysis.
423    *
424    * <p>
425    * For example, in the following class hierarchy, instances of <c>C3</c> will include property <c>p3</c>,
426    * but not <c>p1</c> or <c>p2</c>.
427    * <p class='bjava'>
428    *    <jk>public class</jk> C1 {
429    *       <jk>public int</jk> getP1();
430    *    }
431    *
432    *    <jk>public class</jk> C2 <jk>extends</jk> C1 {
433    *       <jk>public int</jk> getP2();
434    *    }
435    *
436    *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(stopClass=C2.<jk>class</jk>)
437    *    <jk>public class</jk> C3 <jk>extends</jk> C2 {
438    *       <jk>public int</jk> getP3();
439    *    }
440    * </p>
441    *
442    * @return The annotation value.
443    */
444   Class<?> stopClass() default void.class;
445
446   /**
447    * An identifying name for this class.
448    *
449    * <p>
450    * The name is used to identify the class type during parsing when it cannot be inferred through reflection.
451    * <br>For example, if a bean property is of type <c>Object</c>, then the serializer will add the name to the
452    * output so that the class can be determined during parsing.
453    *
454    * <p>
455    * It is also used to specify element names in XML.
456    *
457    * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
458    * <p class='bjava'>
459    *    <jc>// Use _type='mybean' to identify this bean.</jc>
460    *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(typeName=<js>"mybean"</js>)
461    *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {...}
462    * </p>
463    *
464    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
465    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanDictionary(Class...)}
466    * </ul>
467    *
468    * @return The annotation value.
469    */
470   String typeName() default "";
471
472   /**
473    * The property name to use for representing the type name.
474    *
475    * <p>
476    * This can be used to override the name used for the <js>"_type"</js> property used by the {@link #typeName()} setting.
477    *
478    * <p>
479    * The default value if not specified is <js>"_type"</js> .
480    *
481    * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
482    * <p class='bjava'>
483    *    <jc>// Use 'type' instead of '_type' for bean names.</jc>
484    *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(typePropertyName=<js>"type"</js>)
485    *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {...}
486    * </p>
487    *
488    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
489    *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#typePropertyName()}
490    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#typePropertyName(String)}
491    * </ul>
492    *
493    * @return The annotation value.
494    */
495   String typePropertyName() default "";
496
497   /**
498    * Synonym for {@link #writeOnlyProperties()}.
499    *
500    * @return The annotation value.
501    */
502   String wo() default "";
503
504   /**
505    * Write-only bean properties.
506    *
507    * <p>
508    * Specifies one or more properties on a bean that are write-only despite having valid setters.
509    * Parsers will parse such properties as usual, but serializers will silently ignore them.
510    *
511    * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
512    * <p class='bjava'>
513    *    <jc>// Exclude the 'city' and 'state' properties from being serialized, but not parsed.</jc>
514    *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(writeOnlyProperties=<js>"city,state"</js>})
515    *    <jk>public class</jk> Address {...}
516    * </p>
517    *
518    * <h5 class='section'>Notes:</h5><ul>
519    *    <li class='note'>
520    *       {@link #wo()} is a shortened synonym for this value.
521    * </ul>
522    *
523    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
524    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanPropertiesWriteOnly(Class, String)}
525    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanPropertiesWriteOnly(String, String)}
526    *    <li class='jm'>{@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#beanPropertiesWriteOnly(Map)}
527    * </ul>
528    *
529    * @return The annotation value.
530    */
531   String writeOnlyProperties() default "";
532
533   /**
534    * Synonym for {@link #excludeProperties()}.
535    *
536    * @return The annotation value.
537    */
538   String xp() default "";
539}
